interactivity: its hinged lid could be opened
hapticFeedback: Users reach out and place their hands on the chest’s lid edge and latch. They feel a subtle wooden grain under their fingertips (medium‐fine ridges and slight roughness). As they grip the lid’s front lip and lift, they encounter a smooth but firm hinge resistance: an initial catch followed by steady torque as the lid swings open. At the top of the travel there’s a faint ‘stop’ or click sensation as the hinge reaches its limit. A good physical proxy is a small wooden box with a functioning hinge and simple latch, so users feel both the wood grain and the opening resistance.

When users wrap a finger through the round key ring, they perceive a smooth, polished metal finish—very low friction, cool to the touch. The circular loop is uniform in cross-section and fits snugly around a fingertip. Sliding the key between thumb and forefinger, they feel a slender cylindrical shaft that tapers into a flat bit. A suitable proxy is any ordinary metal key or a small, smooth metal ring: it provides the same slim profile, ring-shaped hold, and slick surface.

Users grasp the pistol’s grip with their palm and fingers, feeling a gently contoured handle. When they depress the trigger with their index finger, they experience a distinct travel with spring-loaded resistance, followed by a crisp click or snap at the end of the pull. A slight kickback vibration is felt against the web of the hand at the moment of ‘fire.’ A toy trigger mechanism or a plastic pistol replica with a spring-loaded trigger makes an ideal proxy, matching the trigger pull force, click feedback, and grip shape.

description: a frisbee that players can throw
outline: holding part feels like a thin plate
hapticFeedback: Users hold the frisbee by pinching its thin outer rim between thumb and fingers. They feel a flat, narrow plastic edge—firm but lightweight—with minimal flex under normal grip forces. When they toss it, they notice the low mass and inertia: it shifts easily in the hand and requires only a gentle acceleration to launch. A standard plastic disc or lightweight lid edge serves as an excellent proxy, giving the same thin-rim profile and light throw weight.

description: a steering wheel in a car
hapticFeedback: Users wrap both hands around the circular rim, feeling a smooth, rounded bar beneath their palms. As they rotate the wheel, they sense continuous, low-friction turning with a subtle detent or resistance that mimics steering torque. The diameter and curvature of the rim fill the hands. A real steering wheel from a pedal-car toy or a rotary hand crank with a similar 40 cm diameter offers the correct rotational feel and rim thickness.

Users press the tomato lightly between fingers and thumb, feeling an easily deformed, compliant surface. The flesh yields under minimal force and rebounds slowly, offering a clear sense of soft, squishy material. There is no hard outline, just uniform give. A stress-ball or foam sphere with low stiffness is the best proxy, replicating the same soft, smashable yield.

inertia: relatively heavy with the center of mass concentrated at one end
hapticFeedback: Users grip the round handle, sensing a smooth cylindrical shaft about 2–3 cm in diameter. The weight is noticeably concentrated toward the head end, so when lifted, they feel a forward-heavy moment that pulls the handle down. Swings produce a shifting center of mass and inertial torque in the wrist. A real metal–wood hammer or weighted training hammer with a heavy head and round wooden or rubber handle gives the correct heft distribution and handle feel.
